entry.title: How to use SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator for SAP Analytics Cloud?
entry.content:
**Updated August 2025**

Welcome to our blog series focused on the SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC).

This guide provides a comprehensive, step-by-step approach to help you estimate the capacity units (CU) needed for your business case (before purchasing) or how you can distribute them across your solution components (after signing a contract) for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) within SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC).

This post belongs to a blog series with 4 parts: 

  • SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator
  • SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator for SAP Analytics Cloud (this post)
  • SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator for SAP Datasphere (coming soon)
  • SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator for SAP Databricks (coming soon)

In SAC within BDC, the Capacity Units (CU) vary by license type and quantity of licenses. 

Following SAP Best Practices, two system types are recommended, one for each: 1) Test/QA and 2) Production.

1) For Test/QA, there is 1 SAC license type:

  • SAC Test:
    • It includes all SAC Planning Professional features but in a non-productive environment
    • Minimum requirement: 20 users to provision a test tenant, which refers to a minimum of 941 CU/Month (or 47.05 CU per user)

2) For production, there are 3 SAC license types:

  • SAC Business Intelligence (or SAC BI): 
    • It includes data exploration, visualization, and predictive analytics for insights and informed decision making. No planning features are available
    • Minimum requirement: 25 users to create a prod tenant (scenario 1), which refers to 640 CU/Month (or 25.60 CU per user)
  • SAC Planning Standard (or SAC Planning Std):
    • It includes basic planning functionalities with integrated predictive capabilities like running simulations, data input and scenario modelling
    • Minimum requirement: ‚ö†Ô∏è  We can't provision a prod tenant only with Planning Std licenses; we need at least 10 Planning Std users and 1 Planning Prof user 
  • SAC Planning Professional (or SAC Planning Prof): 
    • It includes everything in Standard plus advanced planning capabilities, including building planning models, complex data actions, allocation rules, and detailed analysis and forecasting.
    • Minimum requirement: 10 Planning Std users and 1 Planning Prof user (scenario 2), which refers to 1548.93 CU/Month (72.85 CU per user for Planning Std and 820.43 CU per user for Planning Prof)

Below, you can find a summary table for the available licenses according each tenant type. 

Business TypesMinimum of licensesMinimum of CU
Test/QA20 SAC Planning Prof (=SAC Test)941 CU/Month
Production (Scenario 1)25 SAC BI640 CU/Month
Production (Scenario 2)1 SAC Planning Prof and 10 SAC Planning Std 1548.93 CU/Month

üìå  Want to estimate more than the minimum? No problem! Below, you can find a step-by-step:

1. Open SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator.

2. Select your "Hyperscaler" and "Data Center".

3. Click "Add" and double-click "SAP Analytics Cloud".

4. Enter the number of licenses for each SAC license type. In this example, we use 25 for SAC BI, 10 SAC Planning Std and 1 SAC Planning Prof. 

5. The final CU amount will appear in the top-right corner. 

Image 1

Image 2

üëâ  For details on provisioning SAC within BDC, please check out our dedicated blog post. 

üí°  If you want to know more about the different SAC license types, read more here and here.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud: Smarter Currency Conversion with Just Ask
entry.content:
When it comes to making data-driven decisions, numbers alone don‚Äôt always tell the full story, especially when you‚Äôre operating across markets, regions, or currencies. That‚Äôs why SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) makes it easy to bring currency intelligence into your conversations with just ask, our natural language-powered analytics feature. 

Whether you're analyzing revenue in local currencies or tracking global sales performance in EUR or USD, Just Ask helps you get the answers instantly and accurately. No complex scripting or data wrangling is required, just natural questions and smart insights 

Flexible Currency Options, Built for Real-World Business Needs 

Different teams have different reporting requirements; some need dynamic currency switching, while others rely on predefined conversions or local currencies by region. With SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere (DSP), you have a range of options to choose from depending on how your data is modeled. 

Below is a quick overview of the supported scenarios. After the table, we‚Äôll walk you through each one with real-world context and guidance. 

How Just Ask Supports Currency Conversion with SAP Analytics Cloud Models vs. SAP Datasphere Models:

 

 

Conversion Category 

Conversion Type 

Just Ask on SAC Models 

Just Ask on DSP Models 

1 

Based on story-level calculation in SAC 

SAC story-level calculation based on model‚Äôs currency conversion  

‚úÖSupported for basic (non-calculated) measures 

üóìÔ∏è Planned 

2 

Fixed-Measure Conversion as specified in model 

Predefined measures with hardcoded currency conversion applied at model level (e.g., Sales_EUR) 

‚úÖSupported 

‚úÖ Supported 

3 

Currency Dimension 

Target currency (currency concept on model-level) determined dynamically via a linked dimension (e.g., region or entity). Currency varies based on dimension member values. 

‚úÖSupported 
üîÑ Just Ask auto-adds currency dimension for breakdown 

‚ö†Ô∏èSupported, but Just Ask does not auto-add the currency dimension 

4 

Currency as Model Variable 
(set by end user) 

Currency set via model variable; applies at query execution. Can be modified post-query in Just Ask. 

‚úÖ Supported 

üîß Variable can be updated interactively in Just Ask 

‚úÖSupported 

üîßVariable can be updated interactively in Just Ask 

5 

Currency as Model Variable 
(included in end user‚Äôs query) 

Currency model as variable. End user is asking for it in natural language query (e.g., Sales in CAD).  

‚úÖ Supported 

 ‚ùå Not supported 

 

Now, let‚Äôs explore each type in more detail: 

1. Story-level Calculation for Currency Conversion 

Best for: Fast ad hoc queries where users want to convert currencies without pre-built measures. 

With just ask, you can instantly convert currency values at runtime using the model‚Äôs built-in conversion logic. Simply ask a question like: 

‚ÄúWhat were our 2024 sales in EUR?‚Äù 

Just ask pulls the latest conversion rates from the model‚Äôs currency table and returns values in your specified currency without any manual setup. 

Available for SAP Analytics Cloud Universal Models where currency conversion is enabled in the modeler. 

Requirements: 

  • The measure must be non-calculated 
  • The unit type must be defined as "currency" 

Behind the scenes: The booking date is used as the conversion reference, and if you paste the just ask result into your story, the converted measure is automatically created and saved.

Currently not supported for SAP Datasphere models, but support is planned in the future. 

 

2. Fixed Currency Measures 

Best for: Use cases where your model already contains hardcoded currency values. 

If your data model includes measures like Sales_EUR or Revenue_USD, you can easily query those in just ask with no extra steps needed. 

Fully supported in both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere. 

These measures are typically created at the model level during data preparation and remain consistent across dashboards and stories. 

Think of this as a one-time setup option: once fixed currency measures are defined in your model, just ask treats each one like a standard metric with no extra configuration needed. 

 

3. Currency by Dimension 

Best for: Companies that operate across multiple regions and need to report in local currencies. 

Some organizations need to show currency values that align with specific regions or entities. With dimension-based currency measures, the appropriate currency is retrieved dynamically based on a linked dimension like country, business unit, or region. 

In SAP Analytics Cloud models, this is fully supported, and just ask automatically inserts the corresponding currency dimension to the result, making it easy to interpret values without mixing currencies in totals. 

In SAP Datasphere models, this functionality is supported, but just ask won‚Äôt auto-add the currency dimension. That means users must manually add the dimension via the Post Search builder panel or specify it in the query. 

Use this approach when reporting across multiple business units or local subsidiaries; your stakeholders will appreciate seeing values in their native currencies. 

 

4. Model Variable Currency 

Best for: Dashboards and queries where users need flexibility to switch currencies based on preference. 

Model variables offer dynamic control over currency selection. For example, users can switch between USD and EUR using a dropdown or prompt, without changing the structure of the query. 

Supported in both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere 

Just ask allows users to update the variable interactively through the data card, or it can be preset by default in Joule for seamless integration into more advanced workflows. 

 

5. Specifying Currency Variable in the Question 

Best for: Quick, natural language queries using variable-driven currency measure. 

In SAP Analytics Cloud, you can query a variable-driven currency measure and specify the target currency directly in your query. for example: 

‚ÄúShow me SalesVar in CAD.‚Äù 

Just ask automatically parses the request, updates the target currency variable, and shows results accordingly. 

Supported only for SAP Analytics Cloud models. 

 

Built for Flexibility. Ready for Scale. 

Whether you‚Äôre a financial analyst tracking global revenue, a sales leader monitoring regional performance, or an operations manager comparing results across subsidiaries, currency conversion is essential to making confident, context-aware decisions. 

With just ask in SAP Analytics Cloud, you get a system that adapts to your business needs: 

  • Conversational queries that feel intuitive 
  • Multiple currency handling methods, from fixed to dynamic 
  • Smart defaults that prevent common errors like mixed currency aggregation 

 

Looking to do more? 

Just ask is even more powerful when paired with Analytical Insights in Joule, allowing you to bring AI-driven insights into your everyday workflow without leaving the tools you already use. 

Need help modeling currency for just ask in your SAP Analytics Cloud or SAP Datasphere environment? 
Check out our help documentation.

Áõ∏ÂØπËåÉÂõ¥ËæìÂÖ•  

Áî®Êà∑‰ªäÂêéÂèØÂ∞ÜÂä®Âõ†ÁöÑ‰∏çÁ°ÆÂÆöÊÄß‰ª•‚ÄúÁõ∏ÂØπÂÄº‚ÄùÂΩ¢ÂºèÂΩïÂÖ•ÔºåÂç≥‰ª•ÂΩìÂâçÊ®°ÂûãÂü∫Á∫ø‰∏∫ÂèÇÁÖßËÆæÂÆöÂÅèÁßªÈáè„ÄÇÂÅèÁßªÈáèÊó¢ÂèØÁî®ÁôæÂàÜÊØîÔºå‰πüÂèØÁî®ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÊï∞ÂÄºË°®Á§∫„ÄÇÂú®ËæìÂÖ•ËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠ÔºåÁïåÈù¢‰∏ãÊñπÂ∞ÜÂêåÊ≠•ÊòæÁ§∫ÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÁªùÂØπÂÄºÔºå‰æø‰∫éÂç≥Êó∂Ê†∏ÂØπ„ÄÇ 

ÈááÁî®ÂÅèÁßªÈáèÊñπÂºèÂΩïÂÖ•Ôºå‰∏ÄÊñπÈù¢Êõ¥Ë¥¥Âêà‰∏öÂä°ÈÉ®Èó®ÁöÑË°®Ëææ‰π†ÊÉØÔºå‰æø‰∫éÂáÜÁ°ÆÊçïÊçâÂÅáËÆæÔºõÂè¶‰∏ÄÊñπÈù¢ÔºåÂêå‰∏ÄÂΩ±ÂìçÂπÖÂ∫¶ÔºàÂ¶Ç +5%ÔºâÂèØ‰∏ÄÈîÆÂ∫îÁî®‰∫éÂ§ö‰∏™Âä®Âõ†ÔºåÊìç‰ΩúÊõ¥Âä†‰æøÊç∑„ÄÇ

entry.title: Everything You Need to Know About the SAP Young Professionals Program
entry.content:
If you‚Äôre an ambitious graduate looking to launch your tech consulting career, the SAP Young Professionals program might be the opportunity you‚Äôve been waiting for! This free, immersive training experience opens doors to become an SAP Associate Consultant and kick-start your career among SAP's. 

What is the SAP Young Professionals program?

It is a free, 2-3 month intensive training initiative from the SAP Digital Skills Center that aims to equip recent university graduates (with less than 3 years of graduation) with SAP knowledge, soft skills, and certifications that prepare them for SAP consulting-related position within the EMEA region. 

Graduates are trained in SAP technologies such as: SAP S/4HANA , SAP Analytics Cloud ,  Artificial Intelligence , SAP Business Technology Platform , within others ((Modules may vary by cohort or region).

Who is eligible for the program?

Applicants typically need to meet the following criteria.

  • Hold a university degree (Bachelor‚Äôs or higher). 
  • Be a recent graduate (within the past 3 years).
  • Be currently unemployed or underemployed
  • Show strong English proficiency.
  • Be citizens or legal residents of the country where the program is being offered.

Note: Specific requirements may vary depending on country and region.

What does the program include?

Over the course of 2‚Äì3 months, participants will:

  • Earn globally recognized certifications 
  • Gain access to SAP Learning Hub and be trained by SAP specialists 
  • Develop soft skills
  • Have the possibility of starting your career as Associate Consultant in SAP's ecosystem (partners + customers)

Is the program really free?

Yes. The SAP Digital Skills Center delivers this program at no cost to participants as part of SAP‚Äôs mission to close the digital skills gap and support sustainable employment. SAP invests in rising talent to help drive digital transformation across industries.

Is employment guaranteed after completing the program?

While job placement is not guaranteed, one of the key goals of YPP is to connect graduates with SAP partners and customers who are actively hiring. Many graduates secure employment within the SAP ecosystem shortly after completing the program. However, success depends on the graduate's performance, certification results, and engagement throughout the course.

How to apply?

Applications are submitted via üëâ  SAP Digital Skills Center portal.

Keep an eye on the website or SAP‚Äôs social media channels for announcements about new program cohorts in your region.

Written by Valentina Guevara.

entry.title: The evolution of member ordering in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction

This short blog post explains the old ‚ÄúEdit Member Order‚Äù for the Classic Table in the Optimized Design Experience (ODE), how it evolved into "Custom Order" with the New Table Build Experience in ODE proposed in the QRC3 2025, and what happens when you migrate Tables.

Ordering affects readability, storytelling, and how business users consume KPIs. Small UX changes here have big impact, so this is worth a quick, clear look.

 

‚ÄúEdit Member Order‚Äù for [Measures] (in Optimized Design Experience ‚Äì ODE)

In Classic Table (ODE), ‚ÄúEdit Member Order‚Äù is the manual-ordering capability used primarily for [Measures] (including calculated measures). It lets authors control the sequence of measure‚Äôs members at the same level so tables present KPIs in the exact order the business expects.

Default sorts (alphabetical, model order, or value-driven) don‚Äôt always match a narrative. Manual ordering lets you put priority metrics first, arrange measures in a business-friendly sequence, or mirror a report layout stakeholders expect.

To use it, the workflow is as follows:

  1. Open the story and switch to ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù;
  2. Select the table widget and open the ‚ÄúBuilder Panel‚Äù;
  3. Locate the [Measures] you want to reorder in the Builder Panel. Click the ‚Äúthree-dot menu‚Äù on the measure dimension;
  4. Choose ‚ÄúEdit Member Order‚Ä¶‚Äù;
  5. In the Edit Member Order dialog, drag measures to the desired order. ‚ÄúDone‚Äù to apply.

 

‚ÄúCustom Order‚Äù for [Measures] (ODE with New Table Build Experience)

The new approach. When switching to the New Table Build Experience (ODE), the manual ordering for [Measures] was redesigned.

The ordering control for dimension members now lives on the header region and is called ‚ÄúCustom Order‚Äù. This is separate from the Classic measure-centric ‚ÄúEdit Member Order‚Äù and is the natural, header-level experience for arranging rows or columns that come from a dimension. And It puts dimension ordering next to other column header-level actions:

  • Improve discoverability for row/column member ordering.
  • Consolidate table configuration for a clearer, more predictable authoring workflow.

To use it on [Measures], the workflow is now as follows:

  1. Open the story in Optimized Design Experience (ODE) and switch to ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù;
  2. Make sure you have activated the option ‚ÄúSwitch All Tables To New Table Build Experience‚Äù;
  3. In the table widget, right-click the Measure header you want to reorder;
  4. Choose ‚ÄúSort options‚Äù >> ‚ÄúAdd Custom Order‚Ä¶‚Äù from the menu;
  5. In the ‚ÄúCreate Custom Order‚Äù dialog, drag members into the desired sequence or use the movement controls. Create/save to update the table.

 

Migration behavior

Functionally, ordering controls were modernized and surfaced where they make the most sense in the New Table Build Experience.

When you migrate Classic Table to the New Table Build Experience in ODE:

  1. The ‚ÄúEdit Member Order option‚Äù is no longer available;
  2. Any previously defined Member Order on Measure is preserved and displayed as the default;
  3. If you want to change the default order, you can create one or multiple Custom Orders.

 

Demo

 

Conclusion

We modernized ordering so it‚Äôs more discoverable and aligned to the object type: measures order remain managed via the Builder Panel pattern in Classic Table, while all dimension members, including Measures in the New Table Build Experience are reordered from the table column‚Äôs header ‚ÄúSort options >> Custom Order‚Ä¶‚Äù. And Converting Classic Table preserves your predefined orders as the default order.

 

Let us know what you think

We want this transition to be smooth and useful. Do not hesitate to share your feedbacks, it directly influences documentations and product improvements. Tell us:

  • Did your measure orders migrate as expected?
  • Any cases where dimension ordering behaved unexpectedly in the New Table Build Experience?

entry.title: Release Navigator for SAP BTP - What's New in Q3 2025
entry.content:
The Release Navigator for SAP BTP continues to evolve and expand, offering our customers improved resources and streamlined access to product updates.

With the Q3 2025 update, we ensured all content is up-to-date and we are excited to announce the addition of a new product page for SAP Customer Data Solutions as well as some cosmetic UI updates. Read more about the details in this blog post.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Collaborating closely with SAP BTP experts, we've expanded the release coverage by introducing 11 new product pages. These pages compile links to all available release information, such as schedules, pre- and post-release communications, blogs, and more:

  • SAP Customer Data Solutions, including
    • SAP Customer Data Cloud / SAP Customer Identity and Access Management
    • SAP Customer Data Platform

Read on to see what you can find on this new page.

SAP Customer Data Solutions

This page contains specific resources for SAP Customer Identity and Access Management, SAP Customer Data Platform, as well as release resources relevant across different SAP Customer Data Solutions. Here‚Äôs a list of all you can find on this page:

  • SAP Customer Identity and Access Management (CDC)
    • Roadmap Explorer: Upcoming Innovations
    • What‚Äôs New Viewer: Release Notes
    • Customer Influence Campaign
    • SAP Community Tag
  • SAP Customer Data Platform
    • Roadmap Explorer: Upcoming Innovations
    • What‚Äôs New Viewer: Release Notes
    • Customer Influence Campaign
    • SAP Community Tag
  • General Customer Data Solutions Resources
    • SAP BTP Newsletter
    • Enablement Webcasts
    • Subscription link to Cloud Availability Center

Please Note: This page has previously been available via the Release Navigator for Customer Experience. Adding this page to the Release Navigator for SAP BTP reflects the move of SAP Customer Data Solutions from the Customer Experience area to SAP BTP. The page in the Release Navigator for Customer Experience will stay online until the beginning of Q4 2025 for everyone to take note and switch out their potential bookmarks or saved links. After that, only the page within the Release Navigator for SAP BTP will remain available.

Check it out.

 

 

With this last round of updates, we added new visual elements to all release navigators. The UI updates in the Release Navigator for SAP BTP do not affect functionality or performance and are strictly cosmetical.

On the home page also known as the Product Specific page, you will notice that our Welcome and Release Calendar cards have received a facelift for a fresher look and feel. 

On all pages where you can open informational text boxes by hovering over the lightbulb icon, you will see a slight update to the design of these boxes. Content and functionality remain the same. 

As a reminder: These pop-up boxes show up on every page with a lightbulb icon at the top and may be moved around on the page or closed once you are done reading them.

 

 

For centralized information regarding the release of new features for SAP BTP products and services, consult the Consolidated Release Schedule for SAP BTP.

Regarding the Release Navigator updates, refer to this update plan:

*Disclaimer: The schedule is subject to alterations without notice, including potential delays or the integration of changes in subsequent update windows. It doesn't establish a commitment, promise, or legal duty to deliver any material, code, or functionality. Looking into the remaining quarters of 2025, updates will focus on quarterly content maintenance and a steady extension of product coverage. No substantial UI updates are planned for the time being.

 

 

The Readiness@Scale team within SAP Enterprise Support is driven to ensure release readiness across the SAP Enterprise Support portfolio. Our mission is to empower SAP customers to effectively adopt and utilize innovations.

If you have feedback or specific requests for content within the release navigator, feel free to contact us.

Don't forget to explore our team‚Äôs blogs tagged under Readiness@Scale.

Happy navigating!

Readiness@Scale  
SAP Enterprise Support

entry.title: UPDATE: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
After the announcement on July 1st regarding the availability of SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud (public option) via SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), the reaction was of great excitement and interest in learning more about the next steps especially about the tenant rewiring option to move existing tenants to SAP BDC. If you missed the announcement, you could read it here: Announcement: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud - SAP Community

The objective of this blog is to share with you the latest information about the tenant rewiring and what it involves.

First, what does it mean for an SAP Datasphere or SAP Analytics Cloud to be rewired?

A tenant rewiring does not mean artefacts or data migration, it mainly refers to the consumption approach (from a commercial model perspective) of these services, and to the customer facing tool to manage the tenant lifecycles (via SAP for Me).  The tenant itself will remain the same, and the URL of the current tenants will not change either. In addition, there are no additional charges for rewiring an SAP Datasphere or SAP Analytics Cloud tenant to SAP BDC.

Second, how will the tenant rewiring work?

There are two paths for customers when it comes to how the tenant rewiring will work.

Customers may have started their consumption of SAP Datasphere or SAP Analytics Cloud (public option) via one of the following consumption models:

  • A subscription of the services where the tenants are provisioned and managed by SAP
  • A subscription of the services where the tenants are provisioned self-service by customers via the customers SAP BTP Global Accounts.

The tenant rewiring tool will support both models; however, the way the process is triggered will be different.

For the SAP-managed / provisioned tenants, the tenant rewiring will be initiated automatically as soon as you update your subscription with SAP (via your SAP account team) to move your subscription from the standalone product subscription to the SAP BDC subscription. This means that the tenant rewiring will be initiated as part of your subscription change request, and the tenant will automatically move to SAP BDC.

When you have a new subscription to SAP BDC, you will receive an email notification from SAP to log into your SAP for Me account. You will need to activate your BDC cockpit in your appropriate data center. If these steps are done prior to the tenant rewiring process, you will be able to see the rewired tenants in your BDC formation as soon as the process is completed.

NOTE: You must use the same hyperscaler and the same data center for your BDC cockpit as your current standalone subscription. The tenant rewiring tool does not migrate tenants between hyperscalers or data centers.

It is important to mention that the tenant will be available for your end users during the process and there is no tenant downtime required by the tenant rewiring tool.

For the tenants that are provisioned self-service via the customers SAP BTP Global Account, your admin will be able to initiate the tenant rewiring directly via the BTP Global Account, also self-service. The only pre-condition required is that a BDC subscription must pre-exist before triggering the tenant rewiring process to move the tenant to SAP BDC.

The steps are as follows:

  • BTP Admin goes in the BTP Global Account / BTP cockpit and updates the BTP Service instance related to the tenant
  • The request is received by SAP and the process is initiated to update the tenant and move it to BDC
  • Login to SAP for Me and, login to BDC, go to the resources tab where you will be able to find the rewired tenants under ‚Äúbdc-rewired‚Äù resource group.
  • Once the rewiring is completed, the tenant will be visible in BDC

Overall, the tenants are preserved and now will be consumed via SAP BDC.

For more information and step-by-step, visit the tenant rewiring documentation.

SAP Analytics Cloud in this blog refers to the following:

  • SAP Analytics Cloud for business intelligence, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud for planning, standard edition, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud for planning, professional edition, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud, test tenant, public system option

entry.title: üü° Introducing the Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt üî®ü™ô ... COMING SOON
entry.content:
Welcome to the Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt, a chase around important SAP developer-related tools/sites, a challenge to construct a secret phrase, and a chance to win 1000s of points toward the Devtoberfest grand prize.

The hunt officially starts Sept. 25, with the release of the first clue during that day's SAP Developer News, and you have until the end of Devtoberfest, Oct. 24, to complete it.

To get all the clues make sure to SUBSCRIBE TO THIS POST!!

Learn more about the  entire Devtoberfest event in @KevinR's post Devtoberfest 2025 Welcome!.

What you need to find

We have hidden a special phrase, which you need to figure out using the clues from several missions, described in the next section. Along your journey you will do the following:

  1. Visit about 10 different locations related to SAP developers, mostly web sites that are designed to help you in your daily SAP development.
  2. At each location, you will discover a set of hexadecimal digits.
  3. Concatenate the digits together (in the order of the missions) to get one, 37-digit hexadecimal number.
  4. Multiply that hexadecimal number by another secret number, for which we will give a clue.
  5. Take the resulting 38-digit hexadecimal product, and convert it into the secret phrase, using each pair of digits as values for ASCII characters.
  6. Enter the phrase, exactly (case-sensitive, no extra spaces), into the Scavenger Hunt tutorial.‚Äå

Not until the SAP Developer News of Oct. 16 will you have all the pieces to be able to complete the phrase. 

Example Hunt

As an example of what you will have to do, here's a short sample hunt (just a warm-up, no points will be earned). Each mission is independent of the other.

MissionNo. DigitsSAP Web PropertyInstructions
17

SAP Developers YouTube Channel

Go to our SAP Developer YouTube channel. 

Open @Rekha_DR's video "SAP Build Process Automation (Part 1): Build your very first process". Watch it and find the secret 7-digit hexadecimal number in one of the info cards.

You can also see the hex digits in the description.

26SAP Community

Inside this blog post, use the Developer Tools on your browser to inspect the words "SAP Community" in the cell immediately to the left (in this very table) and find the 6-digit RGB ASCII code for the color of the text. 

3None (directly) 

Concatenate the 2 sets of hexadecimal digits (13 in all), in order, and multiply the resulting hexadecimal number by the number of original SAP founders (you can easily find the number on the SAP Wikipedia page).

Convert the resulting hexadecimal number into a phrase, converting each pair of digits into a character using ASCII codes.

üëâIn this blog post, post a comment/picture about the phrase -- but NOT the phrase itself  (like your experiences with or opinion about the phrase, or a picture of something belonging to you that reminds you of the phrase). You won't get any points, but it will be fun and you will be ready for the real scavenger hunt. If you have any trouble with this example hunt, post in the comments.

REMINDER: The above is just an example of how the real scavenger hunt will work. The real scavenger hunt instructions will be described in the rest of this blog post, as clues become available.

 

The (real) hunt

Below are the instructions for finding the hexadecimal digits for the actual scavenger hunt. We will release clues as follows:

  • In the SAP Developer News of Sept. 25, Oct. 2, Oct. 9, and Oct. 16.
  • In this blog each Monday during the first 3 weeks of Devtoberfest.

üëâTo be notified when a new clue is released, SUBSCRIBE TO THIS POST!!

‚Äå When you find the secret phase, just enter it into this Devtoberfest tutorial.

To guide you, we have created a second tutorial -- you do not have to use it, nor do you get any points from it. But you can enter the 1 to 6 digits from each mission to check if you received the correct digits for that mission.

Here are your missions 

MissionNo. DigitsSAP Web PropertyInstructions
12

SAP Developer News

The Developer News comes out each Thursday with the latest about ABAP, CAP, BTP, SAP Build, UI5, Fiori, AI, and all your favorite SAP developer topics. All delivered by some of your favorite Developer Advocates, like DJ, Shilpa Shankar, Thomas Jung, Antonio Maradiaga, Nora von Thenen and the rest of the gang.

Most episodes about 5 minutes. Also available as a Podcast.

Watch the Developer News of Sept. 25
26 To be released Sept. 29
34 To be released Sept. 29
42 Watch the Developer News of Oct. 2
54 To be released Oct. 6
66 To be released Oct. 6
76 Watch the Developer News of Oct. 9
86 To be released Oct. 13
91 To be released Oct. 13
10None (directly) Watch the Developer News of Oct. 16

Good luck!

entry.title: Guide for Inline Translations of Embedded SAC Stories in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 and SAP ESM
entry.content:
Embedded SAC stories in Sales & Service Cloud V2 and SAP ESM include a useful feature called Inline Translation. This feature allows customers to create and manage translations for story-related metadata during story creation or editing.

Inline Translation vs. Metadata Translation vs. Data Translation

It‚Äôs easy to mix up these three terms, so here‚Äôs a simple breakdown:

  • Inline Translation
    Refers to metadata created within an Embedded SAC Story. Examples include the story title, description, page titles, and widget titles. In short, anything you create inside the Embedded SAC environment.
  • Metadata Translation
    Applies to the metadata of Sales & Service Cloud V2 and SAP ESM‚Äîfor example, the titles of data sources and their fields. This feature is not yet supported but will be available soon.
  • Data Translation
    Refers to translations of actual business data, such as code descriptions and extension code lists, in Sales & Service Cloud V2 and SAP ESM. This is already supported.

How to Enable Inline Translation

Enabling Inline Translation is a two-step process. Please note that this needs to be done for each story individually.

Step 1: Enable Translation for a Story

This is a one-time setup per story.

  1. Go to All Settings ‚Üí Analytics ‚Üí Design Stories.
  2. Select the story you want to translate and click Edit.
  3. In edit mode, click the gear icon under the File section, then select Story Details.
  4. In the pop-up window, turn on the Enable Translation toggle and click Save.
  5. After the pop-up closes, save the story again.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Important: The language you are logged in with becomes the source language for that story. This cannot be changed later. Make sure you log in with the correct language before enabling translations.

Step 2: Maintain Translations for Target Languages

This step must be repeated for every target language you want to support.

  1. Open the Embedded SAC story in Edit mode.
  2. From the menu, select Tools ‚Üí Inline Translation (or More ‚Üí Tools ‚Üí Inline Translation).
  3. In the pop-up, choose the Target Language from the dropdown list.
  4. Update the text fields with the translated content. The source language text will appear by default.
  5. Click Done, then save the story.

 

 

 

 

 

 

What Business Users Will See

Once translations are maintained, your business users will automatically see story texts in the language they use to log in to Sales & Service Cloud V2 or SAP ESM.

entry.title: SAP Enterprise Support Academy Newsletter September 2025
entry.content:
Dear customers,
Find here an overview of the SAP Enterprise Support Academy monthly newsletter on latest news, training courses, upcoming sessions, and further educational offerings.
The SAP Enterprise Support Academy provides expert guidance and high impact knowledge transfer services that enable you to innovate and be successful with your SAP solutions.

Subscribe to regularly receive latest news and stay informed about the wide range of educational offerings provided by the SAP Enterprise Support Academy that help you to build the digital skills tailored to your needs.

Preview available live sessions on SAP Support Portal, tailored per region:
APJ | EMEA | Latin America | North America*

Unlock the power of SAP Early Watch Alert

Join our interactive e-learning on SAP EarlyWatch Alert, the cloud-based diagnostic tool delivering weekly insights to enhance system health, performance, & security. Master key metrics, proactive recommendations, & navigation. Get started whenever your time allows.

Full details

Rolling out SAP Ariba Category Management?

Whether you are deploying SAP Ariba Category Management alone or with other SAP Ariba or SAP Business Network solutions, we have you covered. Help your business make the most of SAP Ariba Category Management by requesting a deployment readiness CQC. Ready to request remote services?

Check out our blog

The future of logistics with SAP S/4HANA

Join our Expert-Guided Implementation workshop and unleash the power of logistics in SAP S/4HANA. Discover a common view of all logistics solutions and data, get real-time analytics and easy consumable reporting. Transform your logistics processes and drive digital success.

Register for September 8-11

SAP Analytics Cloud BI Core Skills

In September we host an Expert-Guided Implementation session about model and story development in SAP Analytics Cloud. You will be introduced to key topics of connectivity, security configuration, monitoring, and augmented analytics. Learn to develop and customize stories, manage lifecycles, and stay ahead with new features like just ask and Generative AI.

Register here

Explore the parallel line functionality in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Discover the parallel line functionality‚Äîyour key to separating configuration activities post-go-live. Join us to learn about three-system landscapes, lifecycle management, and how to leverage parallel lines for seamless data migration, testing, and training.

 Access here

New sessions added: SAP BW modernization with SAP Business Data Cloud

We have new virtual classrooms for SAP Business Warehouse modernization with SAP Business Data Cloud now open for registration. Sessions are scheduled for EMEA and North America regions.

Full details in the blog

Watch the replays of our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Early Release Series

From July 21-25, we hosted 21 expert-led live sessions to showcase the highlights of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release. Missed the live sessions? Watch the replays on demand.

More details

SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS/IPS): Open Office Hours for SAP Intelligent Spend and Business Network (Ariba and Fieldglass)

Every two weeks, we host open office hours on Wednesdays to answer questions about migrating to SAP Cloud Identity Services (AIS/IPS). Registration is required, and sessions won‚Äôt be recorded. Our goal is to foster and support the adoption of SAP Cloud Identity Services as the go-forward approach, impacting the usage of Corporate IDP and basic authentication.
 
Save September 9 for the next session and register today

Updates from the last SAP Security Patch Day

Familiarize yourself with the new security patches and their implementation challenges and gain latest insights from the last SAP Security Patch Day.  Marc your calendar for September 18 and get tips & tricks related to the last available security notes.
 
Browse through the session materials or register directly

WalkMe onboarding: First experiences last

The WalkMe customer onboarding team offers a seamless and engaging onboarding experience, empowering WalkMe customers to quickly adopt the solution by providing early guidance, enablement, and resources to create a clear and accelerated path to first value realization.
 
Portal page

Learn More

  • Subscribe here for the newsletter
  • Guidance on signing up
  • ES Academy - All you need to know
  • SAP Enterprise Support Academy Video
  • SAP Enterprise Support Academy at a glance
  • Direct access to SAP Learning Hub (Login with your s-user ID and password)
  • SAP ES Academy Entitlement document
  • FAQ
  • SAP Enterprise Support value maps
  • Upcoming live sessions in your region: APJ | EMEA | Latin America | North America

entry.title: Embedded Analytics - How to Analyze System/Browser/Network Performance ?
entry.content:
How to Analyze System Performance in Embedded Analytics ?

You can analyze your system performance using the Measurement Tool, or viewing a variety of stories that provide statistics and analysis.

 

To access the tool, from the side navigation, choose  System  -   Measurement Tool.

Client Test Score

The client test runs several scripts on the local machine and calculates a normalized score. Using current best practices, the client score can be categorized as follows:

  • Excellent: Score >= 75
  • Good: Score >= 50 and <75
  • Poor: Score < 50

Bandwidth measures the megabits per second (Mbps) transferred from server to client when downloading and uploading data. A higher bandwidth number is better than a lower number.

To improve your client score while keeping your existing hardware configuration, watch out for CPU intensive applications and processes that may have a negative impact on your SAP Analytics Cloud performance. For example:
  • Business video conferencing services
  • Virus scanning
  • Synchronizing shared network drives

Network Test Score

Latency is measured in milliseconds (ms). It describes the time it takes from the starting request until the response arrives. A good latency is a ping rate within a low milliseconds range.

The network score may be negatively affected by other applications consuming the bandwidth, various network configurations, or different network issues. For example:
  • Virtual Private Networks (VPN)
  • Firewalls
  • Corporate bandwidth
  • Internet bandwidth
  • Database performance (live data connections)
  • SAML IdP logon time

Optimize System Performance with the Analysis Tool

As an administrator of an SAP Analytics Cloud tenant, you can use the Performance Analysis Tool and the decision tree below to find resources that will help you resolve performance issues.

Who does this apply to?
  • Users with Read and Update permissions for System Information.
  • Admin and BI Admin standard application roles.

The following instructions apply primarily to SAP Analytics Cloud (public and private). Some sections may also be applicable to SAP Analytics Cloud, Embedded edition depending on feature availability.

Use the Performance Decision Tree

Follow the steps in the following decision tree to find resources that will help you to resolve performance issues.

This image is interactive. Hover over each area for a description. Click highlighted areas for more information.

 Guidance on Performance Testing

Caution

According to the General Terms and Conditions for SAP Cloud Services it is prohibited to perform any action on the cloud service which circumvents or endangers its operation or security.


Please note, performance testing might have a serious effect on private instances as well as on shared instances where the SAP Analytics Cloud tenant resides with multiple customer tenants on same instance. This is important because services being used on a certain system are shared among other customers. Due to that reason, performing stress or performance testing is only allowed on SAP Analytics Cloud Private Edition tenants.
  • When in doubt, reach out to your Account Team (Account Executive or Customer Success Professional) to clarify whether you are allowed to do the performance test or not.
  • Understand that the performance and specifications of non-production environments may not be the same as production environments. UAT performance testing cannot be performed on non-production systems.
  • As this is considered a support operation please notify SAP (through your Account Team) at least 15 business days in advance of the test so we can monitor the systems to avoid any outage.
Caution

A general stress test might create a load that could endanger the operation of the cloud service.

ÊîπËøõÊäòÁ∫øÁªüËÆ°ÂõæÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÊ†áÁ≠æ‰ΩçÁΩÆ 


Êàë‰ª¨‰ºòÂåñ‰∫ÜÊäòÁ∫øÁ±ªÁªüËÆ°Âõæ‰∏≠Êï∞ÊçÆÊ†áÁ≠æÁöÑÊòæÁ§∫‰ΩçÁΩÆÔºå‰ª•ÊèêÂçáÂèØËØªÊÄß„ÄÇÊ†áÁ≠æÁé∞Âú®‰ºöÊ†πÊçÆÂõæË°®Â∏ÉÂ±ÄÂíåÂèØÁî®Á©∫Èó¥ËøõË°åÊõ¥Êô∫ËÉΩÁöÑÊîæÁΩÆÔºå‰ªéËÄåÁ°Æ‰øù‰ø°ÊÅØÂëàÁé∞Êõ¥Âä†Ê∏ÖÊô∞„ÄÇ

entry.title: Seamless Integration of Google Cloud BigQuery with SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
On a recent project, I integrated Google Cloud BigQuery with SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). After exploring both platforms, I‚Äôve put together a simple, step-by-step guide‚Äîplus a few key features‚Äîto help you connect them quickly. BigQuery handles huge datasets with speed, while SAC turns that data into clear reports, dashboards, and plans. Together, they take you from raw numbers to smarter decisions.

In this blog, I‚Äôll show you exactly how to set up the integration‚Äîfrom creating a table in BigQuery to keeping your SAC model updated and refreshed.

Key Benefits of BigQuery‚ÄìSAC Integration

  • Seamless Cloud-to-Cloud Integration ‚Äì No complex middleware; connect directly between GCP and SAC.
  • Analytics Made Simple: SAC lets you turn data into dashboards, forecasts, and actionable insights.
  • Faster Decision-Making ‚Äì SAC visualizations update as soon as data refreshes, giving near real-time insights.
  • Collaboration Made Easy ‚Äì SAC allows teams across finance, operations, and strategy to work with the same live data.
  • Automation ‚Äì Schedule regular refreshes so your dashboards and reports stay up to date automatically.

Prerequisites

Before we dive in, you‚Äôll need:

  1. A Google Cloud project with BigQuery enabled.
  2. Access to an SAP Analytics Cloud tenant with permissions to create models and connections.
  3. A BigQuery dataset and an SAC model that share the same schema. (The column data types in BigQuery must match the dimensions and measures in your SAC model.)

Step 1: Create a Table in Google BigQuery

  1. Open GCP Console and navigate to BigQuery Studio.
  2. Create a Dataset within your GCP project.
  3. Within the dataset, create a Table and define its schema. Ensure the schema aligns with the structure of your SAC model (synchronized dimensions and measures). Since I created a table with multiple data types, you can see its schema in the image below.

  4. Populate the table with data if it‚Äôs empty. You can do this via:

    • Python Notebook in GCP .
    • Manual uploads (CSV/JSON).

Example workflow to load data into a BigQuery table (if it has no existing data): Navigate to 'Notebooks' within your GCP project, open a new notebook, load the data using Python, and then verify that the table is populated with the required test or business data. For this example, I loaded some test data into the table using Python code in a notebook.       

Step 2: Prepare the Model in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

  1. Log in to SAP Analytics Cloud.
  2. Navigate to Modeler and create a Blank Model.
  3. Ensure the model structure (dimensions and measures) matches the BigQuery table schema.The image below shows the measures and dimensions, with data types matching those in the BigQuery table.

Step 3: Create a Connection Between SAC and BigQuery

  1. In SAC, go to Main Menu > Connections.
  2. Click on Add Connection (+).
  3. Choose Google BigQuery.
  4. Sign in using the same Google account linked to your GCP project.
  5. Once authenticated, select the relevant Project from the dropdown.
  6. Save the connection. You‚Äôve now linked SAC with your BigQuery environment.

Step 4: Import Data from BigQuery into SAC

  1. Navigate to your SAC model and open Data Management.
  2. Select Import Job.
  3. Choose Google BigQuery as the data source.
  4. Select the connection you created earlier.

      5. Choose between:

  • Freehand SQL Query (for custom queries).
  • Build a Query (drag-and-drop interface) (For most use cases, Build a Query works best: - Select your dataset and table. - Add all required dimensions and measures. - Finalize your query). Here, I chose the Build a Query option, as shown in the image below.

6.  Configure the import job by:

  • Preparing the data.
  • Mapping dimensions to facts
  • Reviewing and confirming the import steps.

7. Run the import. Once completed, SAC will display a success notification along with row-level details in the job timeline.

Step 5: Validate the Imported Data

  1. Navigate back to your Model Structure Workspace in SAC.
  2. Verify that the data has been successfully imported.
  3. Ensure measures and dimensions are mapped correctly.
  4. Test the model with basic visualizations or planning functions to confirm accuracy.
  5. As shown in the image below, the entire BigQuery table is now visible in the Data Foundation area.

Step 6: Refresh and Schedule Your Import Job

One-time imports are fine for demos, but real business data changes constantly. Luckily, SAC lets you refresh and schedule updates:

  • Update: Brings in the latest changes while keeping existing data.
  • Append: Adds new rows without touching what‚Äôs already there.
  • Clean and Replace: Wipes the old dataset and replaces it with fresh data.

You can also schedule refreshes (daily, weekly, or custom) so your dashboards are always up to date ‚Äî no manual work required.

Key Takeaways

  • Integration is straightforward once the schemas in BigQuery and SAC are aligned.
  • BigQuery serves as a powerful backend, while SAC empowers users with visualization and planning tools.
  • Refresh options and scheduling help keep your models in sync automatically

Conclusion

Integrating Google BigQuery with SAP Analytics Cloud isn‚Äôt complicated, but it‚Äôs incredibly powerful. With just a few steps, you can combine BigQuery‚Äôs scalable data engine with SAC‚Äôs interactive analytics and planning features. Whether you‚Äôre experimenting with test data or working at an enterprise level, the process is the same: build your table, set up your model, connect, import, validate, and schedule updates.

By following the steps in this guide, you can set up the integration with ease and keep your models refreshed automatically.
